content:
The protests in Tunisia have been largely driven by economic grievances, particularly high unemployment and inflation, which have been exacerbated by the COVID-19 pandemic. 

Tunisia has struggled with high levels of unemployment in recent years, particularly among young people. According to World Bank data, the youth unemployment rate in Tunisia was 35.8% in 2020. The COVID-19 pandemic has made the situation worse, as lockdowns and restrictions have led to job losses and reduced economic activity.

Inflation has also been a factor causing low purchasing power for Tunisians, with the annual inflation rate reaching 7.5% in 2021. This has led to an increase in the cost of living, including basic necessities like food and fuel, which have become increasingly unaffordable for many Tunisians.

The government has implemented various economic policies intended to address these issues, including reducing public spending and reforming the tax system. However, many Tunisians feel that these measures have not gone far enough, and have called for more far-reaching reforms, including increased investment in job creation, reduced corruption, and better public services.
